Graphical abstract Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts (40wt.-%) were prepared by the citrate method and used without pre-reduction in the thermal catalytic decomposition (TCD) of CH4 at 650°C. The reaction was studied by the thermogravimetric method, monitoring the real time mass change of the catalyst due to reduction by CH4 and carbon deposition. The direct activation of the samples in CH4 was affected by the catalyst composition. While the simultaneous occurrence of catalyst reduction and carbon formation was observed for catalysts consisting mostly of NiO, carbon deposition over catalysts with higher Fe contents only started after an extensive reduction of the samples. Formation of Fe–Ni alloys occurred in the bimetallic catalysts during TCD of CH4, which strongly affected both carbon deposition and deactivation rates of the samples. As a result, the carbon yield of the bimetallic catalysts was slightly higher than that of the monometallic catalyst. The structural properties of the deposited carbon were highly dependent on the catalyst composition, going from a highly disordered turbostratic carbon on the Fe–containing catalysts to a well-ordered almost graphitic carbon on the monometallic Ni sample. Keywords Carbon nanotubes Catalyst reduction Methane decomposition Fe–Ni catalyst Thermogravimetric analysis 1 Introduction In recent years, thermal catalytic decomposition (TCD) of methane has brought much interest since it is the single step process for the production of CO x –free hydrogen [1–4]. TCD of methane also produces carbon in the form of layers, filaments, fibers or nanotubes as an added value [5]. Specially, the formation of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) is of high interest due to their superior physical and chemical properties, such as high tenacity, high electron conductivity, excellent field emission and semiconductor properties [6]. Therefore, CNTs have potential applications in the areas of electronic, energy storage, nanocomposites and medical field. In particular, Ni–based catalysts have attracted the attention of majority of researchers due to their high catalytic activity in TCD of methane at moderate temperatures (500–700°C) [1–4,7]. Other metal catalysts such as Fe, Cu, Co have been also examined. Investigation of iron-containing catalysts is of great interest because the literature data indicates that CO disproportionation and decomposition of hydrocarbons over iron catalysts is accompanied by the formation of CNTs [8]. The properties of Fe–containing catalysts depend on the preparation method, amounts of the metal and reaction temperature. In general, best properties in TCD of methane at 625–700°C were found for Fe/Al2O3 catalysts prepared by the co-precipitation method and containing not less than 50wt.-% of Fe [8,9]. Additionally, bimetallic Fe–Ni, Fe–Co and Fe–Mo catalysts have been studied in TCD of methane at reaction temperatures of 600–700°C, and some of these catalysts provided a superior activity and stability than monometallic Fe catalysts in the production of CO x –free hydrogen and multiwall CNTs [7,8,10,11]. The presence of metal particles is indispensable for the decomposition of methane [12], thus pre-reduction of catalysts is needed. However, it has been reported that when unreduced Ni and Co catalysts are directly used in TCD of methane, the catalytic activity is similar or even higher to that observed over the corresponding pre-reduced samples [13–16]. This raises the prospect of conducting the entire activation procedure in CH4, including reduction, thereby obviating the need for expensive process hydrogen. To our knowledge, direct activation of calcined Fe based catalysts during TCD of methane has not been reported, probably due to the poor reactivity of iron oxide with fuels [17]. Consequently, the purpose of the present work is to study the direct activation in CH4 of calcined Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts for the production of CNTs at 650°C. The effect of Fe-to-Ni weight ratios on the catalytic performance and carbon deposition properties of Fe–Ni/ZrO2 was systematically investigated by the thermogravimetric method, monitoring the real time mass change of the catalyst due to reduction by CH4 and carbon deposition. The support of choice in the present study was zirconia because of its chemical properties such as strong interactions with the active phase, high thermal stability, being more chemical inert than classical oxides, and being the only metal oxide that may possess all four chemical properties: acidity, basicity, and reducing and oxidizing abilities [18,19]. Furthermore, many important industrial reactions have been reported to show higher activity and selectivity when using ZrO2 instead of conventional supports such as Al2O3, SiO2 and TiO2 [19,20]. It has been suggested that zirconia interacts with iron, changing the catalytic properties of the Fe particles [21]. However, very few studies have been devoted to use ZrO2–supported catalysts containing Fe and Ni oxides and for the thermal decomposition of methane. 2 Experimental Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts (40wt.-% of Fe+Ni) were prepared by the sol-gel method using citric acid (AC) as the chelating agent. In a typical procedure, calculated amounts of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, ZrOCl2·8H2O and C6H8O7·H2O were concurrently dissolved in 30mL of demineralized water (Total metal concentration=0.22M; AC-to-metals molar ratio=1.0), and the pH of the solution was adjusted to 1.0 using HNO3. The obtained mixture was dehydrated at 80°C with continuous stirring until a thick gel was formed. The resulting gel was dried at 140°C for 18h and then powdered. The subsequent calcination was carried out in air by heating the gel in a furnace from room temperature to 650°C with increments of 50°C every 30min, and maintaining the maximum temperature for 3h. The calcined catalysts obtained were denoted as xFe–yNi/ZrO2, where x and y were, respectively, the weight-% of Fe and Ni. The elemental composition of the catalysts was determined by ICP–AES. About 100mg of the catalyst was placed in a PTFE beaker and dissolved in a 30mL solution consisting of 10mL of 40% HF, 2mL of HNO3 and 2mL of HCl. The PTFE beaker was placed in an ultrasonic bath for 10min, rinsed into a centrifuge tube and centrifuged at 3000rpm for 3min. The clear supernatant was decanted and used to prepare a 250mL stock solution. Surface areas of the calcined samples were measured using the BET method by N2 adsorption at 77K in a homemade apparatus. Adsorption and desorption of the adsorbate from a N2/He mixture were followed using a thermal conductivity detector. Before each measurement, the sample was degassed at 150°C for 6h. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was measured in a Bruker D8-Advance instrument, employing Ni filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.1541nm). Data was collected over a 2θ range from 20 to 70° and phases were identified by matching experimental patterns to entries in Match! 2 software. The crystallite size D was calculated from line width according to the Scherrer equation. D = 0.9 λ β cos θ where β is the line width at half-maximum intensity (in radians) and θ is the Bragg angle. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded in transmission mode with a Nicolet FTIR-Spectrometer 5 DXC in the range of 1000–400cm−1. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) of the calcined catalysts was carried out in an apparatus consisting of a flow system connected to a thermal conductivity cell to follow changes in the composition of the reducing gas (10mL/min H2 plus 55mL/minN2). The samples were placed into a tubular reactor which was heated at a constant rate (10°C/min) to 800°C. Water produced was removed with a liquid nitrogen trap at the outlet of the reactor. Thus, the observed signal was related only to hydrogen consumption. Calibration of the H2 uptake was done by reduction of different amounts of CuO powder. The process of carbon deposition during TCD of methane was studied by the temperature programmed reaction method using a TA Instruments Q-50 thermobalance, monitoring the real time mass change of the catalysts due to reduction by CH4 and carbon deposition. The reaction was done at atmospheric pressure with a gas mixture of 50vol% CH4 in N2. Approximately 10mg of the calcined Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalyst was placed in an Al2O3 pan and heated to 650°C in the reaction gas mixture. Once the reaction temperature was reached, deposition of carbon was followed for 180min. After CH4 decomposition was stopped, the sample was cooled in N2 flow to room temperature. Air was then introduced to the thermobalance and the sample was heated again up to 800°C in order to study the thermal stability of the deposited carbon. All the experiments were done with a heating rate of 20°C/min and a constant flow of 30mL/min. The isothermal studies were performed under similar conditions. For these experiments, the catalyst was heated up to 650°C in N2 and CH4 was switched into the thermobalance once the reaction temperature was reached. Then, the deposition of carbon was monitored for 180min. The morphology of the carbon produced was observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), using a Jeol JSM 6390 instrument operating at 30kV and coupled to a Incax-Sight 7582 energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS). Before the measurements, the samples were coated with gold to avoid charging problems. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of prepared catalysts Table 1 shows the surface areas and the chemical composition of the calcined Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts. The quantities of Fe and Ni obtained agreed fairly well with those theoretically expected. The surface area of the catalysts increased as the amount of Fe increased, suggesting that Fe was better dispersed than Ni. 3.1.1 XRD The Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts were analyzed by XRD to gather information on the solid phase formed during calcination, and the results are shown in Fig. 1 . The diffraction signal at 2θ=30.4–30.5° and the broad peaks centered at 2θ=50.3–50.5 and 60.1–60.4° indicated the presence of tetragonal ZrO2 in all samples. Additionally, the diffraction signals observed for the 20Fe–20Ni and 26.2Fe–13.8Ni/ZrO2 samples at 2θ=28.1, 31.4–31.7, 33.9–34.4 and 53.9–54.0° should be assigned to the presence of monoclinic ZrO2 phase, indicating that during calcination of this catalyst the tetragonal to monoclinic transition of the support could not be avoided as occurred over the other samples. The 40Ni/ZrO2 sample showed the characteristic reflections owing to the presence of NiO phase at 2θ=37.3, 43.4 and 62.9° (Fig. 1a). Hematite (α–Fe2O3) was the major Fe phase detected over the calcined 40Fe/ZrO2 catalyst (Fig. 1e). The signal at 2θ=21.9° could be assigned to the presence of goethite (FeHO2), which could be the hematite precursor formed in the dried gel. The XRD patterns of the bimetallic catalysts (Fig. 1b–d) pointed to the formation of the spinel structure of nickel ferrite (NiFe2O4) during catalyst preparation, which has been reported before for Fe–Ni catalysts [22–24]. The intensities of the peaks due to this phase decreased as the amount of Fe in the catalysts decreased. Additionally, reflections due to the presence of NiO were observed for the 13.8Fe–26.2Ni and 20Fe–20Ni/ZrO2 samples (Fig. 1b and c, respectively). For the 13.8Fe–26.2Ni/ZrO2 catalyst, the relative intensities due to NiO and NiFe2O4 phases suggest that this catalyst consisted mostly of NiO. The crystallite sizes of the phases observed by XRD over the calcined Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts are shown in Table 2 . The crystallite size of the hematite phase in the 40Fe/ZrO2 sample was considerably smaller than that of the NiO in the 40Ni/ZrO2 catalyst. This result suggests that Fe was better dispersed than Ni and agrees with the difference in surface area observed between these catalysts (Table 1). It has been suggested that the interaction of the zirconia support with iron might be stronger than with nickel [18,20,25,26]. Thus, the strong Fe3+ interactions with the hydroxyl groups on the ZrO2 surface promoted the dispersion of the iron oxide particles during calcination and reduce their size, while the weak interactions of nickel with zirconia leaded to the aggregation of the NiO particles that blocked the porous of the support and caused the decreased surface area. Table 2 also shows that the crystallite size of the NiFe2O4 phase in the bimetallic catalysts was similar to that of the hematite phase in the 40Fe/ZrO2 sample. Furthermore, the crystallite size of the NiO phase that was not forming part of the spinel structure in the 13.8Fe–26.2Ni and 20Fe–20Ni/ZrO2 samples was smaller than that in the 40Ni/ZrO2 catalyst and decreased as the amount of Fe in the catalyst increased. This result suggests that the presence of Fe in the catalysts affected the sintering of nickel oxide during calcination, probably trough the Fe–Ni interactions that leaded to the formation of the nickel ferrite compound. A similar trend in the grain size of NiO upon addition of Fe for Ni–Fe/ZrO2 catalysts, have been recently reported by Ren et al. [27]. 3.1.2 FT–IR The surface composition of the calcined Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts was studied by FT–IR spectroscopy, and the spectra are shown in Fig. 2 . The IR spectra showed broad transmissions bands centered at 434–446, 549–587 and 612cm−1 typical for FeO, NiO and ZrO stretching vibrations [23,28]. The transmission band at 722–724cm−1 can be related to the ZrO2 support [28,29]. The IR spectrum of the 20Fe–20Ni and 26.2Fe–13.8Ni/ZrO2 catalysts (Fig. 2c and d, respectively) showed the characteristic strong and broad band of NiFe2O4 at 612–615cm−1, assigned to the tetrahedral MO stretching vibration [30]. Together with those obtained by XRD (Fig. 1), this result confirmed that NiFe2O4 was formed during preparation of the bimetallic catalysts. IR spectrum of the 13.8Fe–26.2Ni/ZrO2 catalyst resembled that of the 40Ni/ZrO2 sample (Fig. 2b and a, respectively), suggesting that NiO is the major phase on the catalyst surface. Relative intensities of the reflections of the NiO and NiFe2O4 phases obtained by XRD analysis (Fig. 1) also suggested that the calcined 13.8Fe–26.2Ni/ZrO2 sample consisted mostly of NiO. 3.1.3 H2–TPR The reducibility of the Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts after calcination was studied by H2–TPR, and the reduction profiles are depicted in Fig. 3 . The corresponding T max and the H2 consumption for each reduction step are shown in Table 3 . The absence of reduction peaks in the TPR pattern of the ZrO2 support (not shown) indicated that ZrO2 was not a reducible support material. It has been demonstrated that the ZrO2 surface near the metal particle is slightly reduced at high temperature [27]. Thus, the signals observed in the H2–TPR study could be related only to reduction of Fe and Ni oxide species. It is clear from the results in Table 3 that reduction of the catalysts was incomplete within the experimental conditions of the present study. Differences between the experimental results and those expected for the complete reduction of the samples increased as the Fe wt.-% increased, probably indicating that the amount of unreduced Fe was higher than that of Ni. Fig. 3a shows a three-peak reduction profile for the 40Ni/ZrO2 catalyst. Low and high reduction temperatures represent metal oxide species weak and strongly interacting with ZrO2, respectively [20,27]. Consequently, the reduction peaks appeared at 324 and 344°C could be associated with larger NiO particles that are of similar nature to pure bulk NiO, while the higher temperature reduction peak (385°C) could be attributed to nickel oxide species interacting with the support. Notice that the later disappeared in the 13.8Fe–26.2Ni and 20Fe–20Ni/ZrO2 catalysts, and the corresponding reduction profile showed a single peak centered at 343–346°C (Fig. 3b and c, respectively). Introduction of iron into the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst could be the reason of the absence of NiO species interacting with the support, since interactions of ZrO2 with Fe might be stronger than with Ni, as it was stated above. Table 3 shows that the H2 consumption related to the reduction of NiO to Ni0 in the 13.8Fe–26.2Ni and 20Fe–20Ni/ZrO2 catalysts was considerably lower than that theoretically expected. It has to be considered that part of the nickel oxide in these samples was incorporated into the spinel structure of NiFe2O4, whose reduction occurred at higher temperatures (see below). Fig. 3e shows that the 40Fe/ZrO2 catalyst was reduced in two main steps. The H2 consumption related to the signal at T max =476°C most likely corresponded to reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 (Table 3). The second step (T max =658°C) corresponded to the reduction of Fe3O4 to metallic Fe. Reduction of Fe2O3 is known to occur in two or three steps, depending on the reduction conditions [22,31,32]: Fe2O3 →Fe3O4 →Fe or Fe2O3 →Fe3O4 →FeO(Fe0.947O,wüstite)→Fe Table 3 shows that the H2 consumption related to the reduction peaks at 460–463°C for the bimetallic catalysts could also be assigned to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. As it was shown above, the XRD patterns and the FT–IR spectra of the calcined bimetallic catalysts (Figs. 1 and 2, respectively) pointed to the formation of nickel ferrite during sample preparation. Furthermore, the absence of the reduction signal at lower temperatures for the 26.2Fe–13.8Ni/ZrO2 catalyst suggests that all the NiO was incorporated into de spinel structure of NiFe2O4. It has been reported that, with increasing temperature, the products for the reduction of NiFe2O4 appeared in the order [33,34]: NiFe2O4 →Fe3O4 +NiO→Fe3O4 +Ni→FeO+Fe−Nialloy→Fe−Nialloy+Fe Thus, the reduction signals at 635–642°C in the bimetallic catalysts could be assigned to reduction of NiO and Fe3O4 to Ni0 and Fe0, respectively, with the possible formation of a Fe–Ni alloy. Fig. 3 also shows that the reduction of the bimetallic catalysts was easier than the reduction of the 40Fe/ZrO2 sample. Fe–support interactions become weaker as the Fe content decreases [18], which improves the reducibility of the Fe–containing catalysts. Also, the enhanced reducibility of Fe–M systems (M=Ce, Co, Cu, Ni, Zn) has been described in other studies [22,30,31,35–39], and an easier activation of hydrogen over bimetallic systems was proposed [22,30,35]. An electronic effect of Fe and Ni species could be the reason for the enhanced reduction of NiFe2O4 [27]. 3.2 TCD of CH4 at 650°C 3.2.1 Direct activation in CH4 of the calcined catalysts TCD of methane at 650°C was studied by the thermogravimetric method, monitoring the real time mass change of the catalyst during reaction. Reduction by CH4 of the calcined Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts was observed in each test during the continuous heating ramp from room temperature to 650°C at 20°C/min and previously to mass gain due to carbon deposition. Percentages in brackets represent weight-% losses calculated through integration of DTG profiles, after fitting to Gaussian curves using Math Lab R2014a software (R 2 >0.97). These weight losses were compared to those expected for the total reduction of NiO and Fe2O3, calculated from data in Table 1 as follows w t − % = M O ( x M N i + 3 2 y M F e ) where x and y are, respectively, the weight-% of Ni and Fe in the catalysts as reported in Table 1, and MO , MNi and MFe are the molar masses of oxygen, nickel and iron, respectively (15.9994, 58.693 and 55.847g/mol). TG and DTG curves shown in Fig. 4 revealed several distinct weight variation features depending on the composition of the catalyst. All the samples showed a weight loss during the first 10min in CH4 flow (T <250°C), which could be attributed to pre-drying and/or desorption of adsorbed species. This first loss represented≈2–4% of the initial sample weight and it was used to correct the weight loss for each calcined Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalyst, due to reduction by CH4. Fig. 4a shows that the direct activation of the calcined 40Ni/ZrO2 catalyst in CH4 was centered at 417°C. The weight loss before the observation of mass gain due to carbon deposition was 1.7%, a negligible quantity when compared to the weight loss expected for the total reduction of NiO to metallic Ni for this catalyst (10.9%). Thus, the reduction of the catalyst was far for complete when the deposition of carbon begun. Notice that carbon deposition over this sample started at 437°C, a temperature considerably lower than the final reaction temperature. The activation profile of the calcined 13.8Fe–26.2Ni/ZrO2 catalyst resembled that of the monometallic Ni sample (Fig. 4b). XRD and FT–IR analysis (Figs. 1 and 2) seemed to indicate that this calcined catalyst consisted mostly of NiO. Carbon deposition over this sample begun long before the final reaction temperature was reached. This sample showed two weight loss features centered at 257 and 417°C. The weight loss centered at 257°C must be considered a genuine reduction feature of NiO by CH4 [15]. The weaker Ni–support interactions in the presence of Fe over this sample, as suggested by H2–TPR analysis, could allow its reduction by CH4 at lower temperatures than for the 40Ni/ZrO2 catalyst. The weight loss before the observation of mass gain due to carbon deposition was 4.5%, a quantity higher than that observed for the monometallic Ni catalyst, but still lower than that expected for the total reduction of this catalyst (12.8%). Again, the reduction of this sample was largely incomplete when carbon deposition started. However, the presence of metal particles is indispensable for the decomposition of methane [12]. Therefore, present results for 40Ni and 13.8Fe–26.2Ni/ZrO2 catalysts pointed towards the simultaneous occurrence of catalyst reduction and methane decomposition under the actual reaction conditions. As observed before by several authors [13–16], metal oxides can be directly reduced by CH4 under TCD reaction conditions. H2O and CO x have been detected at the reactor outlet due to the reaction of H2 and the deposited carbon with metal oxides, and with vapor or with metal oxides, respectively [13,14]. The 20Fe–20Ni/ZrO2 catalyst showed two weight loss features centered at 397 and 597°C (Fig. 4c). Notice that these temperatures were considerably higher than those of the features observed for the 13.8Fe–26.2Ni/ZrO2 sample, and that carbon deposition over the former started 1min after the final reaction temperature was reached. Notice also that the weight loss before the observation of mass gain due to carbon deposition was 11.7%, close to that expected for the total reduction of the catalyst to metallic Fe and Ni (13.7%). As the 13.8Fe–26.2Ni/ZrO2 sample, the 20Fe–20Ni/ZrO2 catalyst consisted of a mixture of NiO and NiFe2O4 (Fig. 1c), but FT–IR analysis seemed to indicate that nickel ferrite was the major phase on the surface of this sample (Fig. 2c). With increasing amounts of Fe in the catalyst, reduction by CH4 of the calcined catalyst showed weight loss features centered after the final reaction temperature was reached, and weight losses very close to those expected for the total reduction of the catalysts. For the 26.2Fe–13.8Ni and 40FeNi/ZrO2 samples (Fig. 4d and e), the weight losses recorded before the observation of mass gain due to carbon deposition were 12.2 and 13.5%, respectively, while those expected for the total reduction of the samples were 14.6 and 17.0%, respectively. Also, the mass gain due to carbon deposition over these samples was first observed, respectively, after 6 and 10min at 650°C. Hence, these results suggest that almost the complete reduction of the Fe and Ni oxide species was necessary for the carbon deposition to start over catalysts with higher Fe contents. It is clear from data in Fig. 4 that the presence of Ni in the bimetallic Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts recovered the low reduction kinetics of Fe2O3 in CH4, as the reduction temperatures decreased with increasing amounts of Ni. On the other hand, present results suggest that in the presence of Fe, probably through formation of NiFe2O4, the combination of catalyst reduction and methane decomposition, as observed for the 40Ni/ZrO2 catalyst, was attenuated or nonexistent. Differences in the kinetics of reduction of NiO, Fe2O3 and NiFe2O4 should be responsible of the variations observed during direct activation by CH4 of present catalysts. Kuo et al. reported that NiO has higher reduction kinetics in CH4 when compared to Fe2O3 and NiFe2O4 [17]. Additionally, these authors found that the reduction of hematite under CH4 atmosphere at temperatures above 570°C occurs in the same three steps than those reported under H2 (see previous section). XDR analysis on intermediate iron oxides indicates that a partially reduced sample is composed mainly of Fe3O4, and peaks of metal iron are observed only when the sample is completely reduced [17]. Thus, while the metal active centers for carbon formation are present in partially reduced Ni catalysts, over calcined Fe samples these are formed, and hence carbon deposition could start, solely upon the complete reduction of the catalysts, which seems to be corroborated by results in Fig. 4. Reduction of NiFe2O4 by CH4, as that of NiO, appears to occur in one step process [17], indicating that the addition of Ni could recover the low reduction kinetics of Fe2O3 [17,22,35,36], as previously stated from data in Fig. 4. However, experimental results indicate that below 900°C reduction of nickel ferrite by CH4 is dominated by solid-state diffusion [17], which is the transport of metal from sites where oxygen is removed to others where nucleation and grain growth occur, and hinders the reduction kinetics of materials. On the other hand, solid-state diffusion control could retard the formation of metal active centers with suitable particle sizes for carbon growth. It has already proposed that the particle size of metal active centers determines de carbon yield in TCD of CH4 [8,40–44]. For Ni-supported catalysts, it has been observed that Ni metal particles aggregate by the contact with CH4, forming larger particles than those on the fresh catalyst [40,43]. Considering the results presented in Fig. 4 for the calcined 20Fe–20Ni and 26.2Fe–13.8Ni/ZrO2 catalysts, which consisted mostly of NiFe2O4 as indicated by XRD and FT–IR analysis (Figs. 1 and 2), it is possible that the particle size of the metal active centers formed by the partial reduction of this sample, and controlled by solid-state diffusion, was not large enough for carbon growth to start, and consequently the combination of the catalyst reduction and methane decomposition, as observed for catalysts with higher Ni contents, was absent. 3.2.2 Activity of Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts The results of the isothermal studies of the decomposition of methane at 650°C are presented in Fig. 5 , and the catalytic activity of the calcined Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts is shown by means of the variation with time of the carbon yield and the specific rate of carbon formation (r c), defined as r C = 1 W c a t d m d t ( g C g c a t min ) where W cat is the mass of the catalyst, t is the time on stream and m is the mass gain due to carbon deposition as recorded by the thermobalance. Notice that in Fig. 5, t =0 represents the time at which carbon deposition begins. Additionally, the insert graphic in Fig. 5 shows the weight changes of the catalysts during the first 15min of reaction. In this graphic, t =0 indicates the time at which the reaction temperature (650°C) is reached. It is observed that an induction period was needed for the calcined 20Fe–20Ni, 26.2Fe–13.8Ni and 40Fe/ZrO2 catalysts before the observation of mass gain due to carbon deposition. During this induction period, a weight loss was observed in the samples, related to the reduction of the catalysts by CH4, as previously observed in Fig. 4. The induction times and the weight losses observed in Fig. 5 were similar to those of the temperature programmed experiments. In contrast, no induction period was found for the 13.8Fe–26.2Ni and 40Ni/ZrO2 samples, where carbon deposition was observed at the time that the reaction temperature was reached and CH4 was switched into the thermobalance. As stated above, these results suggest that almost the complete reduction of the Fe and Ni oxide species was necessary for the carbon deposition to start over catalysts with higher Fe contents, while the combination of catalyst reduction and methane decomposition was observed only for catalysts consisted mostly of NiO. Fig. 5 shows that the final carbon yield of the calcined 40Ni/ZrO2 catalyst (4.31gC/gcat) was considerably higher than that of the 40Fe/ZrO2 (1.68gC/gcat). The initial carbon deposition rate for this catalyst (r c =0.47gC gcat −1 min−1) was also higher than that of the 40Fe/ZrO2 sample (0.13gC gcat −1 min−1), indicating that the monometallic nickel catalyst was significantly more active in TCD of methane at 650°C. It has been proposed that the direct reduction of the catalyst by CH4 during the TCD reaction, as suggested by data in Fig. 4, enhances the decomposition of methane by shifting the reaction equilibrium to the direction of hydrogen and carbon production [13]. Conversion of H2 and C into H2O and CO x in the presence of the lattice oxygen on the calcined catalyst breaks the original reaction equilibrium of methane decomposition and increasing its reaction rate significantly. As it was shown in Fig. 4, the simultaneous occurrence of catalyst reduction and CH4 decomposition was not observed for the monometallic Fe catalyst. Yet, both 40Fe/ZrO2 and 40Ni/ZrO2 catalysts showed a fast decline of r c, i.e. a high deactivation rate, which completely deactivated the catalysts (r c =0) within the first 85 and 105min of reaction, respectively. Introduction of Fe to the nickel catalyst significantly affected the carbon deposition rate, which decreased as the Fe weight-% increased. Particularly for the 13.8Fe–26.2Ni/ZrO2 sample, this result suggests that Fe–Ni interactions and formation of NiFe2O4 during calcination hindered the enhanced effect of the combination of catalyst reduction and methane decomposition, even when this calcined catalyst consisted mostly of NiO, as suggested by XRD and FTIR analysis (Figs. 1 and 2). However, the incorporation of iron to the nickel catalyst also affected the deactivation rate, which significantly decreased as the Fe content in the bimetallic samples increased. Notice in Fig. 5 that deactivation for the bimetallic samples was not complete after 180min of reaction. As a result, the carbon yield of the bimetallic catalysts was slightly higher than that of the monometallic Ni catalyst. Comparing the carbons yields presented here with those reported before for pre-reduced catalysts, the catalytic performance of the present non-pre-reduced Ni and Fe/ZrO2 samples were, in general, better than those of catalysts prepared by impregnation of the supports or by precipitation of support suspensions with salt solutions. Thereby, at similar reaction temperatures (600–700°C), and after total deactivation of the catalysts, the carbon yield of the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst was higher than those reported for Ni catalysts supported on SiO2, MgO and ZrO2 [45–47], and similar to that reported for Ni/Al2O3 catalysts by Rahman et al. [48]. In regard to the Fe/ZrO2 catalyst, the carbon yield observed for this sample was higher than those of 32 and 50wt-% Fe-Al2O3 catalysts reported by Avdeeva et al. [8], and similar to that of a 50wt-% Fe/SiO2 catalyst reported by Pudukudy and Yaakob [47]. However, carbon yields of the present monometallic catalysts were considerably lower than those reported for catalysts obtained by co-precipitation [8,49–52], the fusing method [53,54] and other sol-gel methods [55]. Similar to that of the monometallic catalysts, the carbon yield of the present non-pre-reduced bimetallic samples was significantly lower than those over catalysts prepared by co-impregnation [56,57]. 3.2.3 Characterization of the spent catalysts XRD analysis of the calcined catalysts after TCD of methane at 650°C was performed in order to identify the changes in the samples that may have occurred during reaction. Besides the diffractions signals at 2θ=30.2–30.4, 50.2 and 60.0–60.2°, assigned to the tetragonal ZrO2 phase, Fig. 6 shows that all the Ni–containing catalysts presented reflections at 2θ=28.1–28.4 and 31.8–32.4°, assigned to the monoclinic ZrO2 phase. These results indicate that TCD of CH4 over the present Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts occurred with destabilization of the tetragonal zirconia phase and hence with a tetragonal to monoclinic transition. The patterns presented in Fig. 6 pointed to the reduction of the samples under reaction conditions. Only diffraction peaks at 2θ=44.6 and 52.0° due to metallic nickel were observed for the spent 40Ni/ZrO2 catalyst (Fig. 6a). This result corroborates the simultaneous occurrence of catalyst reduction and methane decomposition during TCD reaction over the calcined catalyst, as suggested by data from Fig. 4. The combination of catalyst reduction and carbon deposition could be the reason for the higher carbon deposition rate for the monometallic Ni sample. For the spent 40Fe/ZrO2 sample (Fig. 6e) diffraction peaks at 2θ=40.7 and 64.9° could be assigned to the α–Fe phase. The former peak, together with those at 2θ=37.6, 39.8, 42.8, 43.7, 45.9, 49.1 and 51.8° also indicate the presence of the Fe3C phase. Fe3C is formed by decomposition of CH4 on the surface of the catalytic particle. Since Fe3C is metastable under certain conditions, it is decomposed to form filamentous carbon and α-Fe, the latter being active to methane decomposition. Therefore, the presence of Fe3C and α-Fe in the catalytic particle is necessary for oriented carbon growth [11]. The spent bimetallic samples showed diffraction peaks at 43.7–43.8° and 50.9–51.0° that could be assigned to Fe–Ni alloys instead of individual metals (Fig. 6b–d). The peak shifts observed with respect to the reflections expected for metallic Ni and α–Fe phases seemed to confirm this assumption. Formation of Fe–Ni alloys in Fe–Ni catalysts due to reduction with H2 or during reaction has been previously reported [22–24,33,57–61]. Their structure strongly depends on the concentration of the metal added and the reduction conditions. It is proposed that Fe–Ni alloys are the active phase for CNTs growth [57]. As suggested by results in Fig. 5, the catalytic activity of Fe–Ni alloys, in terms of the carbon deposition initial rates, was lower than that of the Ni and Fe phases in the monometallic catalyst. In addition, formation of a Fe–Ni alloy over the 13.8Fe–26.2Ni/ZrO2 sample (Fig. 4b) appeared to diminish the enhanced effect of the simultaneous reduction of the catalyst and decomposition of CH4 in the catalyst activity. Nevertheless, formation of Fe–Ni alloys stabilized the catalysts by decreasing their deactivation rate. As a result, the life time and the carbon yield of the bimetallic catalysts were greater than those of the monometallic catalysts. It has been found that the diffusion of carbon atoms in Fe is higher than that in the Ni phase [58]. While decreasing the carbon deposition rate, the addition of Fe to Ni-based catalysts may enhance the carbon diffusion rate. Thus, the balance among the carbon atom formation and diffusion rates is maintained [57,61], and the stability of the catalyst is enhanced, as observed in the present work. Fig. 6 shows that, after TCD of CH4 at 650°C, all the catalysts showed a sharp reflection at 2θ=26.2–26.5° with (002) plane, attributed to the deposition of graphite on the catalysts surface. SEM micrographs of the spent Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts (Fig. 7 ) shows important differences with changes in the sample composition. On the 40Ni/ZrO2 catalyst (Fig. 7a) CNTs were very few. However, EDX analysis on various regions of the catalyst showed an average C:(Ni+Zr) weight ratio of 4.9:1.0, which is consistent with the high carbon yield observed for this sample (Fig. 5). Thus, these results suggest that carbon should have deposited over the monometallic Ni catalyst as uniform coatings on the Ni particles, which are associated with a rapid deactivation of the catalyst [53], as it was observed for this sample. For the spent bimetallic catalysts, SEM micrographs show a large increase in the density of the mass of CNTs (Fig. 7b and c). The CNTs were twisted and exhibited a wider range of diameters. The density of the mass of CNTs decreased on the 40Fe/ZrO2 catalyst (Fig. 7d) and CNTs appeared to be shorter, which is consistent with the low carbon yield and the high deactivation rate observed for the monometallic Fe catalyst (Fig. 5). The thermal stability of the deposited carbon over the Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts was studied using TGA and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . The data obtained from TGA and DTG curves are tabulated in Table 4 . The onset, inflection and end temperatures represent the temperatures at the initial weight loss, the maximum weight loss, and the final weight loss, respectively. The structural properties of the deposited carbon were also studied through the calculation of the crystallite size (L c) using the Scherrer equation from the XRD line with (002) plane, and the respective lattice constant c of the hexagonal graphitic cell. The results are also shown in Table 4. Fig. 8 shows a single carbon oxidation feature for all the catalysts. According to the data from Table 4, the weigh losses were observed after 450°C, indicating the higher crystallinity of the deposited carbon without any amorphous content, since the amorphous carbon oxidizes before 400°C [24]. Table 4 also shows that the oxidation of the carbon deposited over the Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts was completed at T >650°C, indicating the high thermal stability of the carbon deposited. However, the onset, inflection and end temperatures tended to decrease as the Fe wt.-% ratio increased. On the other hand, the difference between de onset temperature and the end temperature tended to increase with the Fe content. The highest inflection temperature was observed for the 40Ni/ZrO2 catalyst; this sample also showed the lowest difference between initial and end temperatures. According to Chen et al. [62], high inflection temperatures and small differences between the onset and end temperatures indicate the presence of highly graphitized carbon deposit. Thus, the results in Table 4 indicate the formation of ideal graphitized carbon deposits with higher thermal stability over the monometallic Ni catalyst. On the contrary, the increasing difference between the initial and end temperatures, together with the decreasing inflection temperature, observed for the bimetallic catalysts suggested the presence of defects in the deposited carbon. Table 4 shows that the crystallite size of the carbon deposited was higher for the 40Ni/ZrO2 catalysts than for the Fe–containing samples. The lattice constant c tended to increase as the Fe wt.-% increased from a value of 0.6729nm for the monometallic Ni sample up to a value of 0.6787nm for the 26.2Fe–13.8Ni/ZrO2 catalyst. Taking into account that the value of c for a perfect graphite is equal to 0.6704nm, these results suggest that the structural properties of the deposited carbon were highly dependent on the catalyst composition, going from a highly disordered turbostratic carbon on the Fe–containing catalysts, associated with carbon deposition as long nanofibers, to a well-ordered almost graphitic carbon on the monometallic Ni sample, associated with the formation of uniform coatings on the Ni particles that rapidly leads to catalyst deactivation, as it was observed in the present work. 4 Conclusions Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts were prepared by the citrate method and used without pre-reduction for the decomposition of CH4 at 650°C. The composition of the catalyst strongly affected its direct activation in CH4. While the simultaneous occurrence of catalyst reduction and methane decomposition was observed over the catalysts consisting mostly of NiO, carbon deposition over the catalysts with higher Fe contents only started after an extensive reduction of the samples. The formation of Fe–Ni alloys occurred during TCD of methane over the bimetallic catalysts, which strongly affected both carbon deposition and deactivation rates. The carbon deposition rate over Fe–Ni alloys was lower than those of the Ni and Fe phases on the monometallic samples. Still, Fe–Ni alloys stabilized the catalytic activity by decreasing the deactivation rate of the catalysts. Due to this effect, the carbon yield of the bimetallic catalysts was higher than that of the monometallic catalysts. The structural properties of the deposited carbon were highly dependent on the catalyst composition, going from a highly disordered turbostratic carbon on the bimetallic catalysts to a well-ordered almost graphitic carbon on the monometallic Ni sample, associated with the formation of uniform coatings on the Ni particles that rapidly leads to catalyst deactivation. coredata.dc:description: Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts (40wt.-%) were prepared by the citrate method and used without pre-reduction in the thermal catalytic decomposition (TCD) of CH4 at 650°C. The reaction was studied by the thermogravimetric method, monitoring the real time mass change of the catalyst due to reduction by CH4 and carbon deposition. The direct activation of the samples in CH4 was affected by the catalyst composition. While the simultaneous occurrence of catalyst reduction and carbon formation was observed for catalysts consisting mostly of NiO, carbon deposition over catalysts with higher Fe contents only started after an extensive reduction of the samples. Formation of Fe–Ni alloys occurred in the bimetallic catalysts during TCD of CH4, which strongly affected both carbon deposition and deactivation rates of the samples. As a result, the carbon yield of the bimetallic catalysts was slightly higher than that of the monometallic catalyst. The structural properties of the deposited carbon were highly dependent on the catalyst composition, going from a highly disordered turbostratic carbon on the Fe–containing catalysts to a well-ordered almost graphitic carbon on the monometallic Ni sample.
coredata.dc:title: Production of carbon nanotubes through combination of catalyst reduction and methane decomposition over Fe–Ni/ZrO2 catalysts prepared by the citrate method
